comments:
Finance 203 studies the major decision-making areas of managerial finance and some selected topics in financial theory. The course reviews the theory and empirical evidence related to the investment and financing policies of the firm and attempts to develop decision-making ability in these areas. FNCE 203 serves as an extension of FNCE 100. Some areas of financial management not covered in FNCE 100 are covered in FNCE 203. These may include leasing, mergers and acquisitions, corporate reorganizations, financial planning and working capital management, and some other selected topics. Other areas that are covered in FNCE 100 are covered more in depth and more rigorously in FNCE 203. These include investment decision making under uncertainty, cost of capital, capital structure, pricing of selected financial instruments and corporate liabilities, and dividend policy. 

Student reviews on this course was very mixed, but tended to be more negative than positive. While some students stated that the case component of the course “takes a ton of time” and that they were often “pretty lengthy projects,” others believed that the cases “really developed their modeling skills and improved understanding of Corporate Finance.” Many students disliked the fact that cases due on the day of a quiz in essence double-penalized them for mistakes on the cases, because quizzes were based on the cases. 

Professor Kihlstrom also received mixed reviews. While he was described as “a great lecturer,” students believed that the course was dry. They suggested that Professor Kihlstrom “could capture the students’ attention better if he restructured his lectures in a way that would make his final figures easier to follow.” 

Students described this course as “competitive” because of the many Finance concentrators in this course. Prerequisites for this course include FNCE 100, FNCE 101, STAT 101, and STAT 102.

Finance 203 studies the major decision-making areas of managerial finance and some selected topics in financial theory.  The course reviews the theory and empirical evidence related to the investment and financing policies of the firm and attempts to develop decision-making ability in these areas.  This course serves as an extension of FNCE 100, though some areas of financial management not covered in FNCE 100 are covered in FNCE 203. These may include leasing, mergers and acquisitions, corporate reorganizations, financial planning and working capital management, and some other selected topics.  Other areas that are covered in FNCE 100 are covered more in depth and more rigorously in FNCE 203.  These include investment decision making under uncertainty, cost of capital, capital structure, pricing of selected financial instruments and corporate liabilities, and dividend policy.  

The “lectures were dry but very helpful.”  One student suggested that “teaching more theory as opposed to running through cases would add variety to the course.”  Another said it was a “resourceful class.”  One claimed that the course “could have been amazing, but there was so much ambiguity.”  The cases themselves were interesting and the students admit that the topics encouraged them to take “advanced classes on valuation.”

Students had mixed reviews about Professor Kihlstrom, but most found him underwhelming.  He had trouble capturing the students’ attention and was not “the most charismatic lecturer.”  He doesn’t make the class very exciting, but he “was willing to help at all times.”  Some criticized his teaching method and said that asking questions “to the professor and TAs is nearly always fruitless -- they will never give you a straight answer because the class is so ridiculously competitive.”

One student complained about having quizzes that covered the material from homework due on that same day. Another was “disappointed with how long it took for quizzes to be graded” and suggested the need for a clearer rubric and expectations.  Many complained about the TAs.  Prerequisites for this course are  FNCE 100, FNCE 101, STAT 101, and STAT 102. This class can be used to satisfy a requirement for the Finance Concentration.
